4444 add_newdoc('numpy.core.multiarray', 'ndarray', ('transpose',
  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
4445 """
4446 a.transpose(*axes)
4447  
4448 Returns a view of the array with axes transposed.
4449  
4450 For a 1-D array this has no effect, as a transposed vector is simply the
4451 same vector. To convert a 1-D array into a 2D column vector, an additional
4452 dimension must be added. `np.atleast2d(a).T` achieves this, as does
4453 `a[:, np.newaxis]`.
4454 For a 2-D array, this is a standard matrix transpose.
4455 For an n-D array, if axes are given, their order indicates how the
4456 axes are permuted (see Examples). If axes are not provided and
4457 ``a.shape = (i[0], i[1], ... i[n-2], i[n-1])``, then
4458 ``a.transpose().shape = (i[n-1], i[n-2], ... i[1], i[0])``.
4459  
4460 Parameters
4461 ----------
4462 axes : None, tuple of ints, or `n` ints
4463  
4464 * None or no argument: reverses the order of the axes.
4465  
4466 * tuple of ints: `i` in the `j`-th place in the tuple means `a`'s
4467 `i`-th axis becomes `a.transpose()`'s `j`-th axis.
4468  
4469 * `n` ints: same as an n-tuple of the same ints (this form is
4470 intended simply as a "convenience" alternative to the tuple form)
4471  
4472 Returns
4473 -------
4474 out : ndarray
4475 View of `a`, with axes suitably permuted.
4476  
4477 See Also
4478 --------
4479 transpose : Equivalent function
4480 ndarray.T : Array property returning the array transposed.
4481 ndarray.reshape : Give a new shape to an array without changing its data.
4482  
4483 Examples
4484 --------
4485 >>> a = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4]])
4486 >>> a
4487 array([[1, 2],
4488 [3, 4]])
4489 >>> a.transpose()
4490 array([[1, 3],
4491 [2, 4]])
4492 >>> a.transpose((1, 0))
4493 array([[1, 3],
4494 [2, 4]])
4495 >>> a.transpose(1, 0)
4496 array([[1, 3],
4497 [2, 4]])
4498  
4499 """))

4517 add_newdoc('numpy.core.multiarray', 'ndarray', ('view',
  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
4518 """
4519 a.view([dtype][, type])
4520  
4521 New view of array with the same data.
4522  
4523 .. note::
4524 Passing None for ``dtype`` is different from omitting the parameter,
4525 since the former invokes ``dtype(None)`` which is an alias for
4526 ``dtype('float_')``.
4527  
4528 Parameters
4529 ----------
4530 dtype : data-type or ndarray sub-class, optional
4531 Data-type descriptor of the returned view, e.g., float32 or int16.
4532 Omitting it results in the view having the same data-type as `a`.
4533 This argument can also be specified as an ndarray sub-class, which
4534 then specifies the type of the returned object (this is equivalent to
4535 setting the ``type`` parameter).
4536 type : Python type, optional
4537 Type of the returned view, e.g., ndarray or matrix. Again, omission
4538 of the parameter results in type preservation.
4539  
4540 Notes
4541 -----
4542 ``a.view()`` is used two different ways:
4543  
4544 ``a.view(some_dtype)`` or ``a.view(dtype=some_dtype)`` constructs a view
4545 of the array's memory with a different data-type. This can cause a
4546 reinterpretation of the bytes of memory.
4547  
4548 ``a.view(ndarray_subclass)`` or ``a.view(type=ndarray_subclass)`` just
4549 returns an instance of `ndarray_subclass` that looks at the same array
4550 (same shape, dtype, etc.) This does not cause a reinterpretation of the
4551 memory.
4552  
4553 For ``a.view(some_dtype)``, if ``some_dtype`` has a different number of
4554 bytes per entry than the previous dtype (for example, converting a regular
4555 array to a structured array), then the last axis of ``a`` must be
4556 contiguous. This axis will be resized in the result.
4557  
4558 .. versionchanged:: 1.23.0
4559 Only the last axis needs to be contiguous. Previously, the entire array
4560 had to be C-contiguous.
4561  
4562 Examples
4563 --------
4564 >>> x = np.array([(1, 2)], dtype=[('a', np.int8), ('b', np.int8)])
4565  
4566 Viewing array data using a different type and dtype:
4567  
4568 >>> y = x.view(dtype=np.int16, type=np.matrix)
4569 >>> y
4570 matrix([[513]], dtype=int16)
4571 >>> print(type(y))
4572 <class 'numpy.matrix'>
4573  
4574 Creating a view on a structured array so it can be used in calculations
4575  
4576 >>> x = np.array([(1, 2),(3,4)], dtype=[('a', np.int8), ('b', np.int8)])
4577 >>> xv = x.view(dtype=np.int8).reshape(-1,2)
4578 >>> xv
4579 array([[1, 2],
4580 [3, 4]], dtype=int8)
4581 >>> xv.mean(0)
4582 array([2., 3.])
4583  
4584 Making changes to the view changes the underlying array
4585  
4586 >>> xv[0,1] = 20
4587 >>> x
4588 array([(1, 20), (3, 4)], dtype=[('a', 'i1'), ('b', 'i1')])
4589  
4590 Using a view to convert an array to a recarray:
4591  
4592 >>> z = x.view(np.recarray)
4593 >>> z.a
4594 array([1, 3], dtype=int8)
4595  
4596 Views share data:
4597  
4598 >>> x[0] = (9, 10)
4599 >>> z[0]
4600 (9, 10)
4601  
4602 Views that change the dtype size (bytes per entry) should normally be
4603 avoided on arrays defined by slices, transposes, fortran-ordering, etc.:
4604  
4605 >>> x = np.array([[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]], dtype=np.int16)
4606 >>> y = x[:, ::2]
4607 >>> y
4608 array([[1, 3],
4609 [4, 6]], dtype=int16)
4610 >>> y.view(dtype=[('width', np.int16), ('length', np.int16)])
4611 Traceback (most recent call last):
4612 ...
4613 ValueError: To change to a dtype of a different size, the last axis must be contiguous
4614 >>> z = y.copy()
4615 >>> z.view(dtype=[('width', np.int16), ('length', np.int16)])
4616 array([[(1, 3)],
4617 [(4, 6)]], dtype=[('width', '<i2'), ('length', '<i2')])
4618  
4619 However, views that change dtype are totally fine for arrays with a
4620 contiguous last axis, even if the rest of the axes are not C-contiguous:
4621  
4622 >>> x = np.arange(2 * 3 * 4, dtype=np.int8).reshape(2, 3, 4)
4623 >>> x.transpose(1, 0, 2).view(np.int16)
4624 array([[[ 256, 770],
4625 [3340, 3854]],
4626 <BLANKLINE>
4627 [[1284, 1798],
4628 [4368, 4882]],
4629 <BLANKLINE>
4630 [[2312, 2826],
4631 [5396, 5910]]], dtype=int16)
4632  
4633 """))
4634  
4635

4693 """
4694 geterrobj()
4695  
4696 Return the current object that defines floating-point error handling.
4697  
4698 The error object contains all information that defines the error handling
4699 behavior in NumPy. `geterrobj` is used internally by the other
4700 functions that get and set error handling behavior (`geterr`, `seterr`,
4701 `geterrcall`, `seterrcall`).
4702  
4703 Returns
4704 -------
4705 errobj : list
4706 The error object, a list containing three elements:
4707 [internal numpy buffer size, error mask, error callback function].
4708  
4709 The error mask is a single integer that holds the treatment information
4710 on all four floating point errors. The information for each error type
4711 is contained in three bits of the integer. If we print it in base 8, we
4712 can see what treatment is set for "invalid", "under", "over", and
4713 "divide" (in that order). The printed string can be interpreted with
4714  
4715 * 0 : 'ignore'
4716 * 1 : 'warn'
4717 * 2 : 'raise'
4718 * 3 : 'call'
4719 * 4 : 'print'
4720 * 5 : 'log'
4721  
4722 See Also
4723 --------
4724 seterrobj, seterr, geterr, seterrcall, geterrcall
4725 getbufsize, setbufsize
4726  
4727 Notes
4728 -----
4729 For complete documentation of the types of floating-point exceptions and
4730 treatment options, see `seterr`.
4731  
4732 Examples
4733 --------
4734 >>> np.geterrobj() # first get the defaults
4735 [8192, 521, None]
4736  
4737 >>> def err_handler(type, flag):
4738 ... print("Floating point error (%s), with flag %s" % (type, flag))
4739 ...
4740 >>> old_bufsize = np.setbufsize(20000)
4741 >>> old_err = np.seterr(divide='raise')
4742 >>> old_handler = np.seterrcall(err_handler)
4743 >>> np.geterrobj()
4744 [8192, 521, <function err_handler at 0x91dcaac>]
4745  
4746 >>> old_err = np.seterr(all='ignore')
4747 >>> np.base_repr(np.geterrobj()[1], 8)
4748 '0'
4749 >>> old_err = np.seterr(divide='warn', over='log', under='call',
4750 ... invalid='print')
4751 >>> np.base_repr(np.geterrobj()[1], 8)
4752 '4351'
4753  
4754 """)

4865 memory, in which case you can traverse ``a.base`` for a memory handler.

4941 add_newdoc('numpy.core', 'ufunc',
  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
4942 """
4943 Functions that operate element by element on whole arrays.
4944  
4945 To see the documentation for a specific ufunc, use `info`. For
4946 example, ``np.info(np.sin)``. Because ufuncs are written in C
4947 (for speed) and linked into Python with NumPy's ufunc facility,
4948 Python's help() function finds this page whenever help() is called
4949 on a ufunc.
4950  
4951 A detailed explanation of ufuncs can be found in the docs for :ref:`ufuncs`.
4952  
4953 **Calling ufuncs:** ``op(*x[, out], where=True, **kwargs)``
4954  
4955 Apply `op` to the arguments `*x` elementwise, broadcasting the arguments.
4956  
4957 The broadcasting rules are:
4958  
4959 * Dimensions of length 1 may be prepended to either array.
4960 * Arrays may be repeated along dimensions of length 1.
4961  
4962 Parameters
4963 ----------
4964 *x : array_like
4965 Input arrays.
4966 out : ndarray, None, or tuple of ndarray and None, optional
4967 Alternate array object(s) in which to put the result; if provided, it
4968 must have a shape that the inputs broadcast to. A tuple of arrays
4969 (possible only as a keyword argument) must have length equal to the
4970 number of outputs; use None for uninitialized outputs to be
4971 allocated by the ufunc.
4972 where : array_like, optional
4973 This condition is broadcast over the input. At locations where the
4974 condition is True, the `out` array will be set to the ufunc result.
4975 Elsewhere, the `out` array will retain its original value.
4976 Note that if an uninitialized `out` array is created via the default
4977 ``out=None``, locations within it where the condition is False will
4978 remain uninitialized.
4979 **kwargs
4980 For other keyword-only arguments, see the :ref:`ufunc docs <ufuncs.kwargs>`.
4981  
4982 Returns
4983 -------
4984 r : ndarray or tuple of ndarray
4985 `r` will have the shape that the arrays in `x` broadcast to; if `out` is
4986 provided, it will be returned. If not, `r` will be allocated and
4987 may contain uninitialized values. If the function has more than one
4988 output, then the result will be a tuple of arrays.
4989  
4990 """)
4991

5146 add_newdoc('numpy.core', 'ufunc', ('signature',
  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
5147 """
5148 Definition of the core elements a generalized ufunc operates on.
5149  
5150 The signature determines how the dimensions of each input/output array
5151 are split into core and loop dimensions:
5152  
5153 1. Each dimension in the signature is matched to a dimension of the
5154 corresponding passed-in array, starting from the end of the shape tuple.
5155 2. Core dimensions assigned to the same label in the signature must have
5156 exactly matching sizes, no broadcasting is performed.
5157 3. The core dimensions are removed from all inputs and the remaining
5158 dimensions are broadcast together, defining the loop dimensions.
5159  
5160 Notes
5161 -----
5162 Generalized ufuncs are used internally in many linalg functions, and in
5163 the testing suite; the examples below are taken from these.
5164 For ufuncs that operate on scalars, the signature is None, which is
5165 equivalent to '()' for every argument.
5166  
5167 Examples
5168 --------
5169 >>> np.core.umath_tests.matrix_multiply.signature
5170 '(m,n),(n,p)->(m,p)'
5171 >>> np.linalg._umath_linalg.det.signature
5172 '(m,m)->()'
5173 >>> np.add.signature is None
5174 True # equivalent to '(),()->()'
5175 """))

5183 add_newdoc('numpy.core', 'ufunc', ('reduce',
  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
5184 """
5185 reduce(array, axis=0, dtype=None, out=None, keepdims=False, initial=<no value>, where=True)
5186  
5187 Reduces `array`'s dimension by one, by applying ufunc along one axis.
5188  
5189 Let :math:`array.shape = (N_0, ..., N_i, ..., N_{M-1})`. Then
5190 :math:`ufunc.reduce(array, axis=i)[k_0, ..,k_{i-1}, k_{i+1}, .., k_{M-1}]` =
5191 the result of iterating `j` over :math:`range(N_i)`, cumulatively applying
5192 ufunc to each :math:`array[k_0, ..,k_{i-1}, j, k_{i+1}, .., k_{M-1}]`.
5193 For a one-dimensional array, reduce produces results equivalent to:
5194 ::
5195  
5196 r = op.identity # op = ufunc
5197 for i in range(len(A)):
5198 r = op(r, A[i])
5199 return r
5200  
5201 For example, add.reduce() is equivalent to sum().
5202  
5203 Parameters
5204 ----------
5205 array : array_like
5206 The array to act on.
5207 axis : None or int or tuple of ints, optional
5208 Axis or axes along which a reduction is performed.
5209 The default (`axis` = 0) is perform a reduction over the first
5210 dimension of the input array. `axis` may be negative, in
5211 which case it counts from the last to the first axis.
5212  
5213 .. versionadded:: 1.7.0
5214  
5215 If this is None, a reduction is performed over all the axes.
5216 If this is a tuple of ints, a reduction is performed on multiple
5217 axes, instead of a single axis or all the axes as before.
5218  
5219 For operations which are either not commutative or not associative,
5220 doing a reduction over multiple axes is not well-defined. The
5221 ufuncs do not currently raise an exception in this case, but will
5222 likely do so in the future.
5223 dtype : data-type code, optional
5224 The type used to represent the intermediate results. Defaults
5225 to the data-type of the output array if this is provided, or
5226 the data-type of the input array if no output array is provided.
5227 out : ndarray, None, or tuple of ndarray and None, optional
5228 A location into which the result is stored. If not provided or None,
5229 a freshly-allocated array is returned. For consistency with
5230 ``ufunc.__call__``, if given as a keyword, this may be wrapped in a
5231 1-element tuple.
5232  
5233 .. versionchanged:: 1.13.0
5234 Tuples are allowed for keyword argument.
5235 keepdims : bool, optional
5236 If this is set to True, the axes which are reduced are left
5237 in the result as dimensions with size one. With this option,
5238 the result will broadcast correctly against the original `array`.
5239  
5240 .. versionadded:: 1.7.0
5241 initial : scalar, optional
5242 The value with which to start the reduction.
5243 If the ufunc has no identity or the dtype is object, this defaults
5244 to None - otherwise it defaults to ufunc.identity.
5245 If ``None`` is given, the first element of the reduction is used,
5246 and an error is thrown if the reduction is empty.
5247  
5248 .. versionadded:: 1.15.0
5249  
5250 where : array_like of bool, optional
5251 A boolean array which is broadcasted to match the dimensions
5252 of `array`, and selects elements to include in the reduction. Note
5253 that for ufuncs like ``minimum`` that do not have an identity
5254 defined, one has to pass in also ``initial``.
5255  
5256 .. versionadded:: 1.17.0
5257  
5258 Returns
5259 -------
5260 r : ndarray
5261 The reduced array. If `out` was supplied, `r` is a reference to it.
5262  
5263 Examples
5264 --------
5265 >>> np.multiply.reduce([2,3,5])
5266 30
5267  
5268 A multi-dimensional array example:
5269  
5270 >>> X = np.arange(8).reshape((2,2,2))
5271 >>> X
5272 array([[[0, 1],
5273 [2, 3]],
5274 [[4, 5],
5275 [6, 7]]])
5276 >>> np.add.reduce(X, 0)
5277 array([[ 4, 6],
5278 [ 8, 10]])
5279 >>> np.add.reduce(X) # confirm: default axis value is 0
5280 array([[ 4, 6],
5281 [ 8, 10]])
5282 >>> np.add.reduce(X, 1)
5283 array([[ 2, 4],
5284 [10, 12]])
5285 >>> np.add.reduce(X, 2)
5286 array([[ 1, 5],
5287 [ 9, 13]])
5288  
5289 You can use the ``initial`` keyword argument to initialize the reduction
5290 with a different value, and ``where`` to select specific elements to include:
5291  
5292 >>> np.add.reduce([10], initial=5)
5293 15
5294 >>> np.add.reduce(np.ones((2, 2, 2)), axis=(0, 2), initial=10)
5295 array([14., 14.])
5296 >>> a = np.array([10., np.nan, 10])
5297 >>> np.add.reduce(a, where=~np.isnan(a))
5298 20.0
5299  
5300 Allows reductions of empty arrays where they would normally fail, i.e.
5301 for ufuncs without an identity.
5302  
5303 >>> np.minimum.reduce([], initial=np.inf)
5304 inf
5305 >>> np.minimum.reduce([[1., 2.], [3., 4.]], initial=10., where=[True, False])
5306 array([ 1., 10.])
5307 >>> np.minimum.reduce([])
5308 Traceback (most recent call last):
5309 ...
5310 ValueError: zero-size array to reduction operation minimum which has no identity
5311 """))
5312  
5313 add_newdoc('numpy.core', 'ufunc', ('accumulate',
  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
5314 """
5315 accumulate(array, axis=0, dtype=None, out=None)
5316  
5317 Accumulate the result of applying the operator to all elements.
5318  
5319 For a one-dimensional array, accumulate produces results equivalent to::
5320  
5321 r = np.empty(len(A))
5322 t = op.identity # op = the ufunc being applied to A's elements
5323 for i in range(len(A)):
5324 t = op(t, A[i])
5325 r[i] = t
5326 return r
5327  
5328 For example, add.accumulate() is equivalent to np.cumsum().
5329  
5330 For a multi-dimensional array, accumulate is applied along only one
5331 axis (axis zero by default; see Examples below) so repeated use is
5332 necessary if one wants to accumulate over multiple axes.
5333  
5334 Parameters
5335 ----------
5336 array : array_like
5337 The array to act on.
5338 axis : int, optional
5339 The axis along which to apply the accumulation; default is zero.
5340 dtype : data-type code, optional
5341 The data-type used to represent the intermediate results. Defaults
5342 to the data-type of the output array if such is provided, or the
5343 data-type of the input array if no output array is provided.
5344 out : ndarray, None, or tuple of ndarray and None, optional
5345 A location into which the result is stored. If not provided or None,
5346 a freshly-allocated array is returned. For consistency with
5347 ``ufunc.__call__``, if given as a keyword, this may be wrapped in a
5348 1-element tuple.
5349  
5350 .. versionchanged:: 1.13.0
5351 Tuples are allowed for keyword argument.
5352  
5353 Returns
5354 -------
5355 r : ndarray
5356 The accumulated values. If `out` was supplied, `r` is a reference to
5357 `out`.
5358  
5359 Examples
5360 --------
5361 1-D array examples:
5362  
5363 >>> np.add.accumulate([2, 3, 5])
5364 array([ 2, 5, 10])
5365 >>> np.multiply.accumulate([2, 3, 5])
5366 array([ 2, 6, 30])
5367  
5368 2-D array examples:
5369  
5370 >>> I = np.eye(2)
5371 >>> I
5372 array([[1., 0.],
5373 [0., 1.]])
5374  
5375 Accumulate along axis 0 (rows), down columns:
5376  
5377 >>> np.add.accumulate(I, 0)
5378 array([[1., 0.],
5379 [1., 1.]])
5380 >>> np.add.accumulate(I) # no axis specified = axis zero
5381 array([[1., 0.],
5382 [1., 1.]])
5383  
5384 Accumulate along axis 1 (columns), through rows:
5385  
5386 >>> np.add.accumulate(I, 1)
5387 array([[1., 1.],
5388 [0., 1.]])
5389  
5390 """))

5392 add_newdoc('numpy.core', 'ufunc', ('reduceat',
  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
5393 """
5394 reduceat(array, indices, axis=0, dtype=None, out=None)
5395  
5396 Performs a (local) reduce with specified slices over a single axis.
5397  
5398 For i in ``range(len(indices))``, `reduceat` computes
5399 ``ufunc.reduce(array[indices[i]:indices[i+1]])``, which becomes the i-th
5400 generalized "row" parallel to `axis` in the final result (i.e., in a
5401 2-D array, for example, if `axis = 0`, it becomes the i-th row, but if
5402 `axis = 1`, it becomes the i-th column). There are three exceptions to this:
5403  
5404 * when ``i = len(indices) - 1`` (so for the last index),
5405 ``indices[i+1] = array.shape[axis]``.
5406 * if ``indices[i] >= indices[i + 1]``, the i-th generalized "row" is
5407 simply ``array[indices[i]]``.
5408 * if ``indices[i] >= len(array)`` or ``indices[i] < 0``, an error is raised.
5409  
5410 The shape of the output depends on the size of `indices`, and may be
5411 larger than `array` (this happens if ``len(indices) > array.shape[axis]``).
5412  
5413 Parameters
5414 ----------
5415 array : array_like
5416 The array to act on.
5417 indices : array_like
5418 Paired indices, comma separated (not colon), specifying slices to
5419 reduce.
5420 axis : int, optional
5421 The axis along which to apply the reduceat.
5422 dtype : data-type code, optional
5423 The type used to represent the intermediate results. Defaults
5424 to the data type of the output array if this is provided, or
5425 the data type of the input array if no output array is provided.
5426 out : ndarray, None, or tuple of ndarray and None, optional
5427 A location into which the result is stored. If not provided or None,
5428 a freshly-allocated array is returned. For consistency with
5429 ``ufunc.__call__``, if given as a keyword, this may be wrapped in a
5430 1-element tuple.
5431  
5432 .. versionchanged:: 1.13.0
5433 Tuples are allowed for keyword argument.
5434  
5435 Returns
5436 -------
5437 r : ndarray
5438 The reduced values. If `out` was supplied, `r` is a reference to
5439 `out`.
5440  
5441 Notes
5442 -----
5443 A descriptive example:
5444  
5445 If `array` is 1-D, the function `ufunc.accumulate(array)` is the same as
5446 ``ufunc.reduceat(array, indices)[::2]`` where `indices` is
5447 ``range(len(array) - 1)`` with a zero placed
5448 in every other element:
5449 ``indices = zeros(2 * len(array) - 1)``,
5450 ``indices[1::2] = range(1, len(array))``.
5451  
5452 Don't be fooled by this attribute's name: `reduceat(array)` is not
5453 necessarily smaller than `array`.
5454  
5455 Examples
5456 --------
5457 To take the running sum of four successive values:
5458  
5459 >>> np.add.reduceat(np.arange(8),[0,4, 1,5, 2,6, 3,7])[::2]
5460 array([ 6, 10, 14, 18])
5461  
5462 A 2-D example:
5463  
5464 >>> x = np.linspace(0, 15, 16).reshape(4,4)
5465 >>> x
5466 array([[ 0., 1., 2., 3.],
5467 [ 4., 5., 6., 7.],
5468 [ 8., 9., 10., 11.],
5469 [12., 13., 14., 15.]])
5470  
5471 ::
5472  
5473 # reduce such that the result has the following five rows:
5474 # [row1 + row2 + row3]
5475 # [row4]
5476 # [row2]
5477 # [row3]
5478 # [row1 + row2 + row3 + row4]
5479  
5480 >>> np.add.reduceat(x, [0, 3, 1, 2, 0])
5481 array([[12., 15., 18., 21.],
5482 [12., 13., 14., 15.],
5483 [ 4., 5., 6., 7.],
5484 [ 8., 9., 10., 11.],
5485 [24., 28., 32., 36.]])
5486  
5487 ::
5488  
5489 # reduce such that result has the following two columns:
5490 # [col1 * col2 * col3, col4]
5491  
5492 >>> np.multiply.reduceat(x, [0, 3], 1)
5493 array([[ 0., 3.],
5494 [ 120., 7.],
5495 [ 720., 11.],
5496 [2184., 15.]])
5497  
5498 """))
5499  
5500 add_newdoc('numpy.core', 'ufunc', ('outer',
  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
5501 r"""
5502 outer(A, B, /, **kwargs)
5503  
5504 Apply the ufunc `op` to all pairs (a, b) with a in `A` and b in `B`.
5505  
5506 Let ``M = A.ndim``, ``N = B.ndim``. Then the result, `C`, of
5507 ``op.outer(A, B)`` is an array of dimension M + N such that:
5508  
5509 .. math:: C[i_0, ..., i_{M-1}, j_0, ..., j_{N-1}] =
5510 op(A[i_0, ..., i_{M-1}], B[j_0, ..., j_{N-1}])
5511  
5512 For `A` and `B` one-dimensional, this is equivalent to::
5513  
5514 r = empty(len(A),len(B))
5515 for i in range(len(A)):
5516 for j in range(len(B)):
5517 r[i,j] = op(A[i], B[j]) # op = ufunc in question
5518  
5519 Parameters
5520 ----------
5521 A : array_like
5522 First array
5523 B : array_like
5524 Second array
5525 kwargs : any
5526 Arguments to pass on to the ufunc. Typically `dtype` or `out`.
5527 See `ufunc` for a comprehensive overview of all available arguments.
5528  
5529 Returns
5530 -------
5531 r : ndarray
5532 Output array
5533  
5534 See Also
5535 --------
5536 numpy.outer : A less powerful version of ``np.multiply.outer``
5537 that `ravel`\ s all inputs to 1D. This exists
5538 primarily for compatibility with old code.
5539  
5540 tensordot : ``np.tensordot(a, b, axes=((), ()))`` and
5541 ``np.multiply.outer(a, b)`` behave same for all
5542 dimensions of a and b.
5543  
5544 Examples
5545 --------
5546 >>> np.multiply.outer([1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6])
5547 array([[ 4, 5, 6],
5548 [ 8, 10, 12],
5549 [12, 15, 18]])
5550  
5551 A multi-dimensional example:
5552  
5553 >>> A = np.array([[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]])
5554 >>> A.shape
5555 (2, 3)
5556 >>> B = np.array([[1, 2, 3, 4]])
5557 >>> B.shape
5558 (1, 4)
5559 >>> C = np.multiply.outer(A, B)
5560 >>> C.shape; C
5561 (2, 3, 1, 4)
5562 array([[[[ 1, 2, 3, 4]],
5563 [[ 2, 4, 6, 8]],
5564 [[ 3, 6, 9, 12]]],
5565 [[[ 4, 8, 12, 16]],
5566 [[ 5, 10, 15, 20]],
5567 [[ 6, 12, 18, 24]]]])
5568  
5569 """))
5570  
5571 add_newdoc('numpy.core', 'ufunc', ('at',
  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
5572 """
5573 at(a, indices, b=None, /)
5574  
5575 Performs unbuffered in place operation on operand 'a' for elements
5576 specified by 'indices'. For addition ufunc, this method is equivalent to
5577 ``a[indices] += b``, except that results are accumulated for elements that
5578 are indexed more than once. For example, ``a[[0,0]] += 1`` will only
5579 increment the first element once because of buffering, whereas
5580 ``add.at(a, [0,0], 1)`` will increment the first element twice.
5581  
5582 .. versionadded:: 1.8.0
5583  
5584 Parameters
5585 ----------
5586 a : array_like
5587 The array to perform in place operation on.
5588 indices : array_like or tuple
5589 Array like index object or slice object for indexing into first
5590 operand. If first operand has multiple dimensions, indices can be a
5591 tuple of array like index objects or slice objects.
5592 b : array_like
5593 Second operand for ufuncs requiring two operands. Operand must be
5594 broadcastable over first operand after indexing or slicing.
5595  
5596 Examples
5597 --------
5598 Set items 0 and 1 to their negative values:
5599  
5600 >>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4])
5601 >>> np.negative.at(a, [0, 1])
5602 >>> a
5603 array([-1, -2, 3, 4])
5604  
5605 Increment items 0 and 1, and increment item 2 twice:
5606  
5607 >>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4])
5608 >>> np.add.at(a, [0, 1, 2, 2], 1)
5609 >>> a
5610 array([2, 3, 5, 4])
5611  
5612 Add items 0 and 1 in first array to second array,
5613 and store results in first array:
5614  
5615 >>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4])
5616 >>> b = np.array([1, 2])
5617 >>> np.add.at(a, [0, 1], b)
5618 >>> a
5619 array([2, 4, 3, 4])
5620  
5621 """))

5635 add_newdoc('numpy.core.multiarray', 'dtype',
  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
5636 """
5637 dtype(dtype, align=False, copy=False)
5638  
5639 Create a data type object.
5640  
5641 A numpy array is homogeneous, and contains elements described by a
5642 dtype object. A dtype object can be constructed from different
5643 combinations of fundamental numeric types.
5644  
5645 Parameters
5646 ----------
5647 dtype
5648 Object to be converted to a data type object.
5649 align : bool, optional
5650 Add padding to the fields to match what a C compiler would output
5651 for a similar C-struct. Can be ``True`` only if `obj` is a dictionary
5652 or a comma-separated string. If a struct dtype is being created,
5653 this also sets a sticky alignment flag ``isalignedstruct``.
5654 copy : bool, optional
5655 Make a new copy of the data-type object. If ``False``, the result
5656 may just be a reference to a built-in data-type object.
5657  
5658 See also
5659 --------
5660 result_type
5661  
5662 Examples
5663 --------
5664 Using array-scalar type:
5665  
5666 >>> np.dtype(np.int16)
5667 dtype('int16')
5668  
5669 Structured type, one field name 'f1', containing int16:
5670  
5671 >>> np.dtype([('f1', np.int16)])
5672 dtype([('f1', '<i2')])
5673  
5674 Structured type, one field named 'f1', in itself containing a structured
5675 type with one field:
5676  
5677 >>> np.dtype([('f1', [('f1', np.int16)])])
5678 dtype([('f1', [('f1', '<i2')])])
5679  
5680 Structured type, two fields: the first field contains an unsigned int, the
5681 second an int32:
5682  
5683 >>> np.dtype([('f1', np.uint64), ('f2', np.int32)])
5684 dtype([('f1', '<u8'), ('f2', '<i4')])
5685  
5686 Using array-protocol type strings:
5687  
5688 >>> np.dtype([('a','f8'),('b','S10')])
5689 dtype([('a', '<f8'), ('b', 'S10')])
5690  
5691 Using comma-separated field formats. The shape is (2,3):
5692  
5693 >>> np.dtype("i4, (2,3)f8")
5694 dtype([('f0', '<i4'), ('f1', '<f8', (2, 3))])
5695  
5696 Using tuples. ``int`` is a fixed type, 3 the field's shape. ``void``
5697 is a flexible type, here of size 10:
5698  
5699 >>> np.dtype([('hello',(np.int64,3)),('world',np.void,10)])
5700 dtype([('hello', '<i8', (3,)), ('world', 'V10')])
5701  
5702 Subdivide ``int16`` into 2 ``int8``'s, called x and y. 0 and 1 are
5703 the offsets in bytes:
5704  
5705 >>> np.dtype((np.int16, {'x':(np.int8,0), 'y':(np.int8,1)}))
5706 dtype((numpy.int16, [('x', 'i1'), ('y', 'i1')]))
5707  
5708 Using dictionaries. Two fields named 'gender' and 'age':
5709  
5710 >>> np.dtype({'names':['gender','age'], 'formats':['S1',np.uint8]})
5711 dtype([('gender', 'S1'), ('age', 'u1')])
5712  
5713 Offsets in bytes, here 0 and 25:
5714  
5715 >>> np.dtype({'surname':('S25',0),'age':(np.uint8,25)})
5716 dtype([('surname', 'S25'), ('age', 'u1')])
5717  
5718 """)
5719

5745 add_newdoc('numpy.core.multiarray', 'dtype', ('byteorder',
  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
5746 """
5747 A character indicating the byte-order of this data-type object.
5748  
5749 One of:
5750  
5751 === ==============
5752 '=' native
5753 '<' little-endian
5754 '>' big-endian
5755 '|' not applicable
5756 === ==============
5757  
5758 All built-in data-type objects have byteorder either '=' or '|'.
5759  
5760 Examples
5761 --------
5762  
5763 >>> dt = np.dtype('i2')
5764 >>> dt.byteorder
5765 '='
5766 >>> # endian is not relevant for 8 bit numbers
5767 >>> np.dtype('i1').byteorder
5768 '|'
5769 >>> # or ASCII strings
5770 >>> np.dtype('S2').byteorder
5771 '|'
5772 >>> # Even if specific code is given, and it is native
5773 >>> # '=' is the byteorder
5774 >>> import sys
5775 >>> sys_is_le = sys.byteorder == 'little'
5776 >>> native_code = sys_is_le and '<' or '>'
5777 >>> swapped_code = sys_is_le and '>' or '<'
5778 >>> dt = np.dtype(native_code + 'i2')
5779 >>> dt.byteorder
5780 '='
5781 >>> # Swapped code shows up as itself
5782 >>> dt = np.dtype(swapped_code + 'i2')
5783 >>> dt.byteorder == swapped_code
5784 True
5785  
5786 """))

5825 """
5826 Dictionary of named fields defined for this data type, or ``None``.
5827  
5828 The dictionary is indexed by keys that are the names of the fields.
5829 Each entry in the dictionary is a tuple fully describing the field::
5830  
5831 (dtype, offset[, title])
5832  
5833 Offset is limited to C int, which is signed and usually 32 bits.
5834 If present, the optional title can be any object (if it is a string
5835 or unicode then it will also be a key in the fields dictionary,
5836 otherwise it's meta-data). Notice also that the first two elements
5837 of the tuple can be passed directly as arguments to the ``ndarray.getfield``
5838 and ``ndarray.setfield`` methods.
5839

5989 add_newdoc('numpy.core.multiarray', 'dtype', ('metadata',
  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
5990 """
5991 Either ``None`` or a readonly dictionary of metadata (mappingproxy).
5992  
5993 The metadata field can be set using any dictionary at data-type
5994 creation. NumPy currently has no uniform approach to propagating
5995 metadata; although some array operations preserve it, there is no
5996 guarantee that others will.
5997  
5998 .. warning::
5999  
6000 Although used in certain projects, this feature was long undocumented
6001 and is not well supported. Some aspects of metadata propagation
6002 are expected to change in the future.
6003  
6004 Examples
6005 --------
6006  
6007 >>> dt = np.dtype(float, metadata={"key": "value"})
6008 >>> dt.metadata["key"]
6009 'value'
6010 >>> arr = np.array([1, 2, 3], dtype=dt)
6011 >>> arr.dtype.metadata
6012 mappingproxy({'key': 'value'})
6013  
6014 Adding arrays with identical datatypes currently preserves the metadata:
6015  
6016 >>> (arr + arr).dtype.metadata
6017 mappingproxy({'key': 'value'})
6018  
6019 But if the arrays have different dtype metadata, the metadata may be
6020 dropped:
6021  
6022 >>> dt2 = np.dtype(float, metadata={"key2": "value2"})
6023 >>> arr2 = np.array([3, 2, 1], dtype=dt2)
6024 >>> (arr + arr2).dtype.metadata is None
6025 True # The metadata field is cleared so None is returned

6182 add_newdoc('numpy.core.multiarray', 'dtype', ('newbyteorder',
  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
6183 """
6184 newbyteorder(new_order='S', /)
6185  
6186 Return a new dtype with a different byte order.
6187  
6188 Changes are also made in all fields and sub-arrays of the data type.
6189  
6190 Parameters
6191 ----------
6192 new_order : string, optional
6193 Byte order to force; a value from the byte order specifications
6194 below. The default value ('S') results in swapping the current
6195 byte order. `new_order` codes can be any of:
6196  
6197 * 'S' - swap dtype from current to opposite endian
6198 * {'<', 'little'} - little endian
6199 * {'>', 'big'} - big endian
6200 * {'=', 'native'} - native order
6201 * {'|', 'I'} - ignore (no change to byte order)
6202  
6203 Returns
6204 -------
6205 new_dtype : dtype
6206 New dtype object with the given change to the byte order.
6207  
6208 Notes
6209 -----
6210 Changes are also made in all fields and sub-arrays of the data type.
6211  
6212 Examples
6213 --------
6214 >>> import sys
6215 >>> sys_is_le = sys.byteorder == 'little'
6216 >>> native_code = sys_is_le and '<' or '>'
6217 >>> swapped_code = sys_is_le and '>' or '<'
6218 >>> native_dt = np.dtype(native_code+'i2')
6219 >>> swapped_dt = np.dtype(swapped_code+'i2')

6341 add_newdoc('numpy.core.multiarray', 'busdaycalendar',
  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
6342 """
6343 busdaycalendar(weekmask='1111100', holidays=None)
6344  
6345 A business day calendar object that efficiently stores information
6346 defining valid days for the busday family of functions.
6347  
6348 The default valid days are Monday through Friday ("business days").
6349 A busdaycalendar object can be specified with any set of weekly
6350 valid days, plus an optional "holiday" dates that always will be invalid.
6351  
6352 Once a busdaycalendar object is created, the weekmask and holidays
6353 cannot be modified.
6354  
6355 .. versionadded:: 1.7.0
6356  
6357 Parameters
6358 ----------
6359 weekmask : str or array_like of bool, optional
6360 A seven-element array indicating which of Monday through Sunday are
6361 valid days. May be specified as a length-seven list or array, like
6362 [1,1,1,1,1,0,0]; a length-seven string, like '1111100'; or a string
6363 like "Mon Tue Wed Thu Fri", made up of 3-character abbreviations for
6364 weekdays, optionally separated by white space. Valid abbreviations
6365 are: Mon Tue Wed Thu Fri Sat Sun
6366 holidays : array_like of datetime64[D], optional
6367 An array of dates to consider as invalid dates, no matter which
6368 weekday they fall upon. Holiday dates may be specified in any
6369 order, and NaT (not-a-time) dates are ignored. This list is
6370 saved in a normalized form that is suited for fast calculations
6371 of valid days.
6372  
6373 Returns
6374 -------
6375 out : busdaycalendar
6376 A business day calendar object containing the specified
6377 weekmask and holidays values.
6378  
6379 See Also
6380 --------
6381 is_busday : Returns a boolean array indicating valid days.
6382 busday_offset : Applies an offset counted in valid days.
6383 busday_count : Counts how many valid days are in a half-open date range.
6384  
6385 Attributes
6386 ----------
6387 Note: once a busdaycalendar object is created, you cannot modify the
6388 weekmask or holidays. The attributes return copies of internal data.
6389 weekmask : (copy) seven-element array of bool
6390 holidays : (copy) sorted array of datetime64[D]
6391  
6392 Examples
6393 --------
6394 >>> # Some important days in July
6395 ... bdd = np.busdaycalendar(
6396 ... holidays=['2011-07-01', '2011-07-04', '2011-07-17'])
6397 >>> # Default is Monday to Friday weekdays
6398 ... bdd.weekmask
6399 array([ True, True, True, True, True, False, False])
6400 >>> # Any holidays already on the weekend are removed
6401 ... bdd.holidays
6402 array(['2011-07-01', '2011-07-04'], dtype='datetime64[D]')
6403 """)

  • E128 Continuation line under-indented for visual indent
6650 """
6651 newbyteorder(new_order='S', /)
6652  
6653 Return a new `dtype` with a different byte order.
6654  
6655 Changes are also made in all fields and sub-arrays of the data type.
6656  
6657 The `new_order` code can be any from the following:
6658  
6659 * 'S' - swap dtype from current to opposite endian
6660 * {'<', 'little'} - little endian
6661 * {'>', 'big'} - big endian
6662 * {'=', 'native'} - native order
6663 * {'|', 'I'} - ignore (no change to byte order)
6664  
6665 Parameters
6666 ----------
6667 new_order : str, optional
6668 Byte order to force; a value from the byte order specifications
6669 above. The default value ('S') results in swapping the current
6670 byte order.
6671  
6672  
6673 Returns
6674 -------
6675 new_dtype : dtype
6676 New `dtype` object with the given change to the byte order.
6677  
6678 """))
